\begin{abstract} We introduce a family of standard bigraded binomial Artinian Gorenstein algebras, whose combinatoric structure characterizes the ones presented by quadrics. 
These algebras provide, for all socle degree grater than two and in sufficiently large codimension with respect to the socle degree, counter-examples to Migliore-Nagel conjectures, see \cite{MN1} and \cite{MN2}. One of them predicted that 
Artinian Gorenstein algebras presented by quadratics should satisfy the weak Lefschetz property. We also prove a generalization of a Hessian criterion for the

\section{Introduction}

A standard graded ${\mathbb{K}}$ algebra is said to be presented by quadrics if it is isomorphic to the quotient of a polynomial ring over ${\mathbb{K}}$ by a homogeneous ideal generated by 
quadratic forms. Also called quadratic algebras, they are related with Koszul algebras and Grobner basis, see for example \cite{Co}. 
From a more geometric point of view quadratic ideals appear as homogeneous ideals of very positive embeddings of any smooth projective varieties. 
As pointed out in \cite{MN2}, Artinian Gorenstein algebras presented by quadrics 
are also related to Eisenbud-Green-Harris conjectures motivated by the Cayley-Bacharach theorem. The Lefschetz properties have attracted a great deal of attention over the years, 
in a number of different settings including Commutative Algebra itself, Algebraic Geometry and Combinatorics, see \cite{St,St2,MN1,HMMNWW,HMNW}. 
The present work lies in the border of these three areas.  

More recently, in \cite{MN2} the authors studied Artinian Gorenstein algebras presented by quadrics, they presented some constructions of such algebras and described their 
possible Hilbert vectors. In \cite{MN1} and \cite{MN2} the authors proposed two conjectures, which, from now on, we will call Migliore-Nagel conjectures. 
These conjectures inspired the present paper. 

\begin{conjecture} {\bf (Migliore-Nagel injective Conjecture)} \label{conj:WMNC}
 For any Artinian Gorenstein algebra presented by
quadrics, defined over a field ${\mathbb{K}}$ of characteristic zero, and of socle degree at least three, there exists $L \in A_1$, such that, the multiplication map $\bullet L:A_1 \to A_2$ is injective.
\end{conjecture}


\begin{conjecture} {\bf (Migliore-Nagel WLP Conjecture)}\label{conj:SMNC}
 Any Artinian Gorenstein algebra presented by quadrics, over a field ${\mathbb{K}}$ of characteristic zero, has the Weak Lefschetz Property. That is, there exists $L \in A_1$ such that 
 all the maps $\bullet L: A_i \to A_{i+1}$ have maximal rank.
\end{conjecture}

In \cite{MN2} the authors proved the WLP-conjecture for complete intersection of quadratic forms and presented computational evidence for the conjectures in low codimension. 
We want to stress the fact that as soon as the codimension increases with respect to the socle degree surprising phenomena begin to appear.     

We recall that the Lefschetz properties for standard graded Artinian ${\mathbb{K}}$ algebra are algebraic abstractions introduced by Stanley in \cite{St}, motivated by the 
Hard Lefschetz Theorem on the cohomology rings of smooth irreducible complex projective varieties endowed with the euclidean topology, see for example the survey  
\cite{La} for the theorem and \cite{Ru} for an overview. The PoincarÃ© duality for these cohomology rings inspired the definition of PoincarÃ© duality algebras which, 
in this context, is equivalent to the 
Gorenstein hypothesis, for more details see, for example \cite{MW} and \cite{Ru}. In \cite{Wa2} and \cite{MW} the authors used Macaulay-Matlis duality in characteristic 
zero to present the Artinian Gorenstein algebra as $A=Q/{\operatorname{Ann}}_Q(f)$ where $f \in R={\mathbb{K}}[x_1,\ldots,x_n]$ a polynomial ring and $Q={\mathbb{K}}[X_1,\ldots,X_N]$ the associated ring of differential operators. 
They introduced a Higher Hessian determinantal criterion using a basis of $A_k$ to identify 
Strong Lefschetz elements $L \in A_1$. In \cite{Go} this criterion was used by the first author to contruct explict examples of Artinian Gorenstein algebras that do not satisfy the Strong Lefschetz property 
and/or the Weak Lefschetz property, producing forms with vanishing Hessian of higher order. \par

Hypersurfaces with vanishing (first) Hessian is a classical subject that traces back to Hesse's wrong claim, see \cite{He}, that a form has vanihing Hessian if and only if 
its partial derivatives are linearly independent. Gordan-Noether in the fundamental paper \cite{GN} proved a criterion to the vanishing of the Hessian, 
see Proposition \ref{prop:GNcriteria}. They showed that Hesse's claim is true for at most four variables and produced series of counterexamples for at least five 
variables, these counterexamples exaust all the examples in five variables. A modern proof of this fact can be found in \cite{GR} while a very detailed account on the 
 subject appears in \cite{Ru}. Perazzo in \cite{Pe}  studied cubic hypersurfaces with vanishing Hessian in at most seven variables and found a canonial form that motivated our definition of Perazzo hypersurfaces 
also in degree $d \geq 3$, see Definition \ref{defin:perazzopolynomial}. More recently \cite{CRS}, \cite{Lo}, 
\cite{GR}, \cite{GRu}, \cite{Wa2} and \cite{Ru} treated different aspects of the subject, sometimes called Gordan-Noether Theory.\par

In \cite{GRu}, which contain results from the first author's thesis, Perazzo's work has been revisited from a modern point of view, re-obtaining the classification of cubics with vanishing Hessian in ${\mathbb{P}}^N$ for $N \leq 6$ 
and describing new examples in higher dimension. An important example of cubic with vanishing Hessian in ${\mathbb{P}}^7$, is given by a general tangent section of the secant variety of the Segre variety ${\mathbb{P}}^2\times {\mathbb{P}}^2 \to \operatorname{Seg}(2,2) \subset {\mathbb{P}}^8$, see \cite[p. 803, Example 6]{GRu}. From the algebraic point of view, 
see Example \ref{ex:semplicissimo}, it provides a standard graded Artinian Gorenstein algebra presented by quadrics which does not have the WLP, being a counter example for both 
Migliore-Nagel conjectures. This example was the starting point of our work. \par

Our strategy to construct standard graded Artinian Gorenstein algebras presented by quadrics is to deal with the simplest ones, which are those whose ideal contains the complete intersection 
$(x_1^2,\ldots,x_n^2)$. This assumption forces all monomials that occur in $f$ to be square free. As a matter of fact we deal with bihomogeneous forms of bidegree $(1,d-1)$ of special type, 
here called of monomial square free type, see Definition \ref{defin:bigraded1}, and note the similarity with Perazzo polynomial. To any bihomogeneous form of monomial square free type we can associate in a bijective way 
a pure simplicial complex whose combinatoric structure determine a set of generators of the annihilator ideal, see Theorem \ref{thm:mainideal}. This combinatoric object 
also characterizes when the associated algebra is presented by quadrics, see Theorem \ref{thm:mainpresentedbyquadrics}, wich summarizes the main results of the work. Inspired by the famous 
Turan Theorem, see \cite{Tu}, that characterizes maximal graphs not containing a complete subgraph $K_l$, we introduce a simplicial complex, here called Turan complex, 
whose associated algebra is always presented by quadrics and such that, in sufficient large codimension and arbitrary degree the first multiplication map $\bullet L:A_1 \to A_2$ is not injective for all $L \in A_1$. 
Furthermore, for a particular subfamily, which occurs in very large codimension with respect to the socle degree, the Hilbert vector of $A$ is not even submodal in the first step, that is 
$\dim A_1 > \dim A_2$. \par

We now describe the contents of the paper in more detail. In the first section we recall the basic definitions and constructions of standard graded Artinian Gorenstein algebras, we deal also with 
the bigradedd case which is of particular interest, we recall the Lefschetz properties, Macaulay-Matlis duality and the hessian criterion given in \cite{Wa1} and \cite{MW}. The 
main result of the first section is a generalization of the Hessian criterion to mixed Hessians, see Theorem \ref{thm:hessiancriteria}. We also recall classical results about  
forms with vanishing Hessian that will be useful in the sequel.\par

The second section is devoted to the main results and constructions. Theorem \ref{thm:mainideal} describes the annihilator of a standard bigraded form of bidegree $(1,d-1)$ 
of monomial square free type, showing that it is a binomial ideal whose generators are closely connected with the combinatoric of the associated simplicial complex. 
Theorem \ref{thm:mainpresentedbyquadrics} is the main result. It characterizes when such algebras are presented by quadrics. In this section we introduce the Turan complex 
and as Corollary \ref{cor:matador}, we produce counterexamples to both Migliore-Nagel conjectures in any socle degree and sufficient large codimension. It is surprising 
the fact that if the codimension is very large with respect to the socle degree, the Hilbert vector of the Turan algebras, that are quadratic and binomial, 
is non unimodal in the first step, an unexpected and very surprising fact. 

In the last section we deal with an inductive construction, see Corollary \ref{induction}. In the second subsection we give a complete description of bigraded algebras of monomial square free type of socle bidegree $(1,2)$ that are presented by quadrics 
(see Theorem \ref{prop:maincubic}). In Corollary \ref{cor:cubiccase} we show that for all codimension $r \geq 8$ there are algebras of socle degree $3$ presented by quadrics that does not satisfy the WLP. Furthermore 
the bound is sharp by Corollary\ref{cor:cubics_low_codimension}. For higher odd degree we prove the existence of algebras presented by quadrics that do not satisfy the WLP in all 
codimensions $r \geq d+5$ (see Corollary \ref{cor:existemimpares}). The bound is relatively sharp by the result for $d=3$. In the last subsection we study the case of even socle degree, showing the strong difference with the odd socle degree case. We prove the existence of algebras of socle degree $4$ 
and of codimension $r \geq 16$ that are presented by quadrics but not having the WLP, see Corollary \ref{cor:quarticcase}. 
In the similar way we deal with the even socle degree in general (see Corollary \ref{cor:existempares}). In even socle degree we are not able to give sharp bounds even 
in socle degree $4$. The problem is that, since there is not a classification of quartics with vanishing Hessian in 
${\mathbb{P}}^N$ for $N \geq 5$, there is not an analog of Corollary \ref{cor:cubics_low_codimension}.

\begin{defin}\rm

We say that $A$ has the {\em Weak Lefschetz property} (in short WLP) if there exists a linear form $L\in R_1$ such that

The following Lemma will be useful in the next sections. If $\mathcal{K}$ is a simplicial complex and $l \in \mathcal{K}_{d-2}$ is a $d-2$-face, we construct the 
complex $\mathcal{K}'$ attaching a new facet from $l$ and a new vertex. This facet is said to be a {\em leaf}. Notice that $e'_0=e_0+1$, $e'_i-e_i \geq 2$ for $2\leq i\leq d-2$ and $e'_d=e_d+1$.   

\begin{lema}\label{lema:attachcell}
 Let $\mathcal{K}$ be a $d-1 \geq 2$ dimensional simplicial complex that represents an algebra $A$, presented by quadrics such that $d_1 \leq d_2$ and $e_{d-1}\leq e_{d-2}$. 
 Let $\mathcal{K}'$ be the simplicial complex constructed from $\mathcal{K}$ attaching a leaf. Then the algebra $A'$ given by $\mathcal{K}'$ is presented by quadrics. Furhtermore,  
 $A$ satisfies the injective conjecture if, and only if $A'$ also satisfies.
\end{lema}

\begin{proof}
 It is easy to see that $A'$ is presented by quadrics by Theorem \ref{thm:mainpresentedbyquadrics}. By Lemma \ref{lema:tecnicalhessian}, since $e_1 \leq e_2$ and $e_{d-1} \leq e_{d-2}$, 
 we have that $A$ safisfies the injective conjecture if, and only if ${\operatorname{rk}} {\operatorname{Hess}}_f^{((1,0),(0,d-2))}=e_{d-1}$ and ${\operatorname{rk}} {\operatorname{Hess}}_f^{((0,1),(1,d-3))}=e_{1}$. 
 Since attaching a leaf we still have $e'_1 \leq e'_2$ and $e'_{d-1} \leq e'_{d-2}$  and since it does not alters the fact of the rank of the desired mixed Hessians to be maximal, the result follows.
\end{proof}


\subsection{Artinian Gorenstein algebras with odd socle degree}

Let $A$ be a standard graded Artinian Gorenstein algebra with socle degree three, then $A=Q/{\operatorname{Ann}}_Q(f)$ with $f \in R$ a homogeneous polynomial 
of degree $3$. Theorem \ref{thm:hessiancriteria} applied to this case tells us that $A$ satisfies the WLP if and only if ${\operatorname{hess}}_f \neq 0$.\par

By a result due to Dimca-Papadima, see see \cite[Thm. 1]{DP}, if $f$ is not a reduced polynomial and $\tilde{f}$ is its radical, then ${\operatorname{hess}}_f = 0$ if and only if ${\operatorname{hess}}_{\tilde{}f}=0$. 
For quadratic polynomials not a cone, ${\operatorname{hess}}_{\tilde{f}} \neq 0$, so we can restrict ourselves to reduced cubic polynomials. Furthermore, if $f=f_1f_2$ and ${\operatorname{hess}}_f=0$, then 
all the components of $X = V(f) \subset {\mathbb{P}}^n$ are developable, yielding ${\operatorname{hess}}_{f_i} \equiv 0 \pmod{f_i}$, in this case $f=l_1l_2l_3$ and $X$ is an arrangement of hyperplanes passing through a ${\mathbb{P}}^{N-2}$, which is a cone as soon as 
$N\geq 2$. 
So, from now on we can restric ourselves to the case that $f$ is an absolutely irreducible polynomial.

\begin{thm}\cite{GRu} \label{thm:perazzo} Perazzo hypersurfaces are not cones and have vanishing Hessian. 
Suppose that $N \leq 6$, and let $X = V(f) \subset {\mathbb{P}}^N$ be an irreducible cubic hypersurface which is not a cone and such that ${\operatorname{hess}}_f=0$. 
Then, up to a projective transformation, $f$ is a Perazzo polynomial.
\end{thm}

\begin{cor} \label{cor:cubics_low_codimension} Let $A$ be a standard graded Artinian Gorenstein ${\mathbb{K}}$-algebra of socle degree $3$. 
 If $A$ is presented by quadrics and ${\operatorname{codim}} A \leq 7$, then $A$ satisfy the WLP. 
\end{cor}

\begin{proof} Suppose that $A$ does not have the $WLP$. Then by the Hessian criterion, Theorem \ref{thm:hessiancriteria}, ${\operatorname{hess}}_f=0$.
